1.  Please download the following
    <br>

    <center>
    <a onclick="fetch(&#39;data:text/x-markdown;base64,&#39;).then(res =&gt; res.blob()).then(blob =&gt; {&#10;      const downloadURL = window.URL.createObjectURL(blob);&#10;      const a = document.createElement(&#39;a&#39;);&#10;      document.body.appendChild(a);&#10;      a.href = downloadURL;&#10;      a.download = &#39;Test for Validity and Reliability Rmarkdown file.Rmd&#39;; a.click();&#10;      window.URL.revokeObjectURL(downloadURL);&#10;      document.body.removeChild(a);&#10;    });">
    <button class="btn btn-primary hvr-sweep-to-left"><i class="fa fa-save"></i> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<span style='color:#ffffff'>Download</span></button>
    </a>
    </center>

    <br>
    While a power analysis is ideal for this situation as first step, the point of the task is to get you familiar with a workflow for quantitatively driven surveys.

2.  If you have <b>30 or more responses</b> and <b>more than two columns of quantitative data</b>, then please move to step 3. Otherwise if you

-   only lack a sufficient number of responses but have more than two columns of quantitative data, then simulate the remaining data preferably within Qualtrics
    -   <a href="https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/randbetween-function-4cc7f0d1-87dc-4eb7-987f-a469ab381685" target="_blank">Excel</a>

    -   <a href="https://www.qualtrics.com/support/survey-platform/survey-module/survey-tools/generating-test-responses/" target="_blank">Qualtrics</a>

    -   R (there are many ways to accomplish like <a href="https://www.crumplab.com/programmingforpsych/simulating-and-analyzing-data-in-r.html" target="_blank">this</a> or [that](https://github.com/markolalovic/responsesR))[^1]
-   do not have more than two columns of quantitative data, then please reach out to me via Slack and I will provide a unique real world survey data set you can use for this task

3.  Open the mostly empty Rmarkdown file `Test for Validity and Reliability.Rmd`, read through the directions, and include your syntax to receive credit. It is suggested that you open a separate script and test your R code as needed

4.  Save the resulting PDF file by adding your first initial and last name to the beginning of the filename. For example, my submission would be `aroy Test for Validity and Reliability.pdf`

5.  Submit your PDF output to eCampus in the Submission Portal by the end of Week 13

<center>
<p id="rounded_corners">
All incremental deliverables can be found on the main <a href="/tasks/#deliverables">Tasks</a> page
<p>
</center>

[^1]: Please reach out if you would prefer to simulate data in R but are not able to do so.
